questions.text: Expressive aphasia occurs due to lesions of which of the following area?
questions.solution:
• Expressive aphasia:
    • The lesions of motor speech area of Broca (Option A) result in loss of ability to produce speech, i.e. expressive aphasia (also called motor aphasia).
    • The patients, however, retain the ability to think about the words they wish to say, they can write the words, and they can understand their meaning when they see or hear them.
    • Thus, although the language is understood, it cannot be expressed in speech even though there is no paralysis of muscles of lips, tongue, and vocal cords, etc.
  • Receptive aphasia:
    • Lesions of Wernicke's area (Option B) in the dominant hemisphere produce loss of ability to understand the spoken and written speech. This condition is called receptive sensory aphasia.
  • Global aphasia:
    • Lesions involving both Broca's and Wernicke's speech areas (Option C) result in loss of the production of speech as well as loss of understanding of the spoken and written speech.
    • This condition is called global aphasia.
  • Conductive aphasia:
    • A lesion involving Wernicke's area and superior longitudinal fasciculus or arcuate fasciculus (Option D) results in jargon aphasia in which speech is fluent but unintelligible jargon.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Motor aphasia - lesion of brocas area (area 44,45)

Sensory aphasia - lesion of Wernicke's area(area 22)

Global aphasia - lesion of both brocas and Wernicke's area

Conductional aphasia - lesion of actuate fasciculus.

Topic: Cortical areas of cerebrum

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Page Number - 154, 155

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given figure.
questions.solution:
• Given figure is showing Horizontal section through corpus striatum, thalamus and internal capsule.
  • The marked structure is internal capsule.
    • The internal capsule is a large band of fibres, situated in the inferomedial part of each cerebral hemisphere.
    • In horizontal sections of the brain, it appears V-shaped with its concavity directed laterally. The concavity is occupied by the lentiform nucleus.

Topic: Basal ganglia & Internal capsule

questions.text:
A 45 years old male patient diagnosed with the hemisection of spinal cord at the level of T10 vertebra. Which of the followings symptoms may be seen in that patient?
I. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of lesion
II. Ipsilateral loss of conscious proprioceptive sensations above the level of lesion
III. Contralateral loss of touch sensation below the level of lesion
IV. Ipsilateral upper motor neuron paralysis above the level of injury
questions.solution:
Hemisection of the spinal cord leads to Brown-Sequard syndrome:

  • Signs and symptoms are as follows:
  • Below the level of lesion:
    • Ipsilateral upper motor neuron paralysis caused by pyramidal tract damage.
    • Ipsilateral loss of conscious proprioceptive sensations caused due to damage to posterio white column. So (Symptom-II) is not seen.
    • Due to damage to lateral spinothalamic and anterior spinothalamic tracts
      • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature (Symptom-I)
      • Contralateral loss of touch caused (Symptom-III)
  • At the level of lesion:
    • Ipsilateral lower motor neuron paralysis caused due to damage to ventral nerve roots. So (Symptom-IV) is not seen.
    • Ipsilateral anaesthesia over the skin of the segment due to injury to the ventral nerve roots.
  • Above the level:
    • Ipsilateral hyperaesthesia above the level of lesion due to irritation of dorsal nerve roots.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: BROWN SEQUARD SYNDROME

Ipsilateral loss of dorsal column sensation

Contra lateral loss of pain and temperature

Topic: Spinal cord

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-4, 9th Edition, Page Number - 50, 51 Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Page Number - 73, 74

questions.text: Figure is showing the tracts in the spinal cord. Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
Marked structure is lateral corticospinal tract.

  • The lateral corticospinal tract lies in the lateral white column in front of the posterior horn and medial to the posterior spinocerebellar tract.
  • The anterior corticospinal tract lies in the anterior white column close to the anterior median fissure.

choices.text: Ipsilateral hemiplegia of arm and leg

questions.text: All of the following symptoms are seen in case of medial medullary syndrome, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Medial medullary syndrome (Dejerine's anterior bulbar syndrome:

  • The paramedian region of the medulla is supplied by the branches of vertebral artery mainly anterior spinal artery(ASA)
  • The vascular involvement (ischaemia) of this region produces following signs and symptoms:
    • Contralateral hemiplegia/paralysis of arm and leg, due to damage of pyramid. So (Option A) is wrong.
    • Ipsilateral paralysis and atrophy of the half of the tongue (Option B) due to damage of hypoglossal nerve.
    • Contralateral loss of position sense (Option C) and contralateral loss of vibration sense (Option D) due to damage of medial lemniscus.

Topic: Medulla oblongata

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-4, 9th Edition, Page Number - 21, 24

questions.text: 35 years old male patient was presented to emergency department. He was undergone with cranial angiography. It was diagnosed that patient is having injury to anterior inferior cerebellar artery. All of the following symptoms can be presented in the patient, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Damage to anterior inferior cerebellar artery results in: AICA syndrome
    • Cerebellum: Ipsilateral limb ataxia (Option A).
    • Brainstem: Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, so (Option B) is incorrect.
    • Sensory loss: Pain and temperature of face (Option C).
    • Facial weakness and paralysis of lateral gaze.
    • Contralateral sensory loss: Pain and temperature of trunk (Option D) and limbs.
  • Thrombosis of superior cerebellar artery results in:
    • Cerebellum: Disturbed gait, limb ataxia.
    • Brainstem: Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.
    • Contralateral sensory loss: Pain and temperature (including face).
  • Thrombosis of posterior inferior cerebellar artery results in: PICA syndrome
    • Cerebellum: Dysarthria, ipsilateral limb ataxia, vertigo and nystagmus (due to damage to vestibulofloccular connections).
    • Brainstem: Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.
    • Sensory loss: Pain and temperature of face.
    • Pharyngeal and laryngeal paralysis.
    • Contralateral sensory loss: Pain and temperature of limbs and trunk.

Topic: Blood supply of brain

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by B D Chaurasia, 4th Edition, Page Number 186

questions.text: Which of the following function is not contributed by left hemisphere in right handed person?
questions.solution:
Cerebral hemispheric dominance

  • The term dominant hemisphere refers to the side concerned with the perception and production of language/speech.
  • According to this concept, the left hemisphere is dominant in over 90% of people (right handed person), The left hemisphere controls the right side of the body, including the skilful right hand.
  • During childhood, one hemisphere slowly comes to dominate over the other, and it is only after the first decade that the dominance becomes fixed.

Topic: Cerebral hemisphere

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Page Number 157

questions.text: Which of the following is false about thalamic hand?
questions.solution:
Thalamic syndrome: (DEJERINE ROUSSY SYNDROME)

  • It usually occurs subsequent to a vascular lesion of the thalamus (viz. thrombosis of thalamogeniculate artery) branch of posterior cerebral artery
  • The threshold for pain, touch and temperature is decreased on the opposite side of the body.
  • But when the threshold is reached, the sensations are exaggerated, perverted and disagreeable (thalamic overreaction).

Thalamic hand:

  • It is sometimes seen in thalamic lesions.
  • The opposite hand is held in an abnormal posture.
    • The forearm pronated, so (Option A) is false.
    • The wrist flexed (Option B)
    • The metacarpophalangeal joints flexed (Option C)
    • The interphalangeal joints extended (Option D)
  • The fingers can be moved but slowly, due to altered muscle tone in the different muscle groups.

Topic: Thalamus

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Page Number 134
